Award.AwardTitle: BioMaPS: Experimental and Computational Studies of Microtubule Dynamics and Regulation by Binding Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
The goal of this project is to use coordinated experiment and computational modeling to answer fundamental questions about the system-level behavior of the microtubule cytoskeleton. Microtubules (MTs) are the primary components of crucial subcellular structures including the mitotic spindle, which segregates the chromosomes, and the intracellular transport network, which organizes the cytoplasm. Understanding how MT-based structures assemble, are maintained, and drive cell organization is a central problem in cell biology. MTs exhibit a surprising behavior known as dynamic instability -- individual MT fibers transition randomly between extended phases of growth and depolymerization. The long-term goal of this project is to establish an understanding of DI and its regulation by MT binding proteins by coupling experiment with iterative multi-scale modeling. The specific goals of this research are: 1) Obtain an understanding of, and seek to establish, a set of general principles for how MT binding proteins cooperate to modulate MT dynamics and polymer mass using MT plus-end tracking proteins as a model; 2) Define the relationship between the behavior of the bulk MT polymer and that of individual MTs. A key goal is to use modeling approaches to investigate and refine classical theories of equilibrium polymers that define MT dynamics. While the focus is on MTs, the improved understanding should be relevant to other cytoskeletal polymers; 3) Develop freely disseminated software packages with associated tools and instructional electronic tutorials to help students and researchers gain an intuitive understanding of dynamic MT systems using computational models of MT assembly.

BROADER IMPACTS
This projects combined modeling and experimental effort will help students and researchers at all levels gain an intuitive understanding of dynamic MT systems. This understanding is important for applications ranging from nanotechnology (the mitotic spindle is a striking example of a self-organized nanotechnological system) to controlling agricultural pests (some prominent antiparasitic and antifungal compounds are directed at MTs). The PIs will integrate the software tools developed as part of this project into their classes. The project will also educate graduate and undergraduate students who will benefit from interdisciplinary training in biology and computational modeling. Projects related to this research will be incorporated in The Research Experience for Teachers at Notre Dame program as well as into programs promoting graduate and doctoral studies for minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
BACKGROUND

The goal of this project was to further develop our existing fine-grained computational model of subcellular structures called microtubules (MTs) and use a combination of this computational model and wet-lab experiments to gain a predictive understanding MT dynamics and their regulation by MT binding proteins (MTBPs). Microtubules are a key part of the cytoskeleton, the dynamic network of filaments and associated proteins that gives cells shape and enables them to move and organize themselves internally. Combining simulations and experiments is essential to creating a predictive understanding of microtubule dynamics because systems of dynamic MTs exhibit emergent properties that are not straightforwardly predictable from the characteristics of the tubulin subunits that make up the microtubules, or even from the MTs themselves.

Achieving the goal of establishing a predictive understanding of microtubule dynamics would be significant because MTs are the primary components of crucial subcellular structures including the intracellular transport network and the mitotic spindle, and a central problem in cell biology is to understand how these MT-based structures form, are dynamically maintained, and drive the organization of the rest of the cell. Building an improved understanding of microtubule dynamics would also have practical applications for developing improved compounds that target MTs (e.g., herbicides, fungicides), as well for harnessing the self-organizing properties of MTs in nanotechnology and synthetic biology.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The efforts funded by this grant resulted four interdisciplinary PhD theses and 12 publications. Significant advances include the following:

• We combined experiments and simulations to resolve long-standing questions about the mechanism of the cancer-associated MTBP OP18/stathmin.[1] This work provides insight into how overproduction of stathmin by cancer cells can help the cancer cells resist microtubule-targeted therapies such as Taxol. 

• We provided a hypothesis for why many microtubule binding proteins (MTBPs) bind to each other in a network of loose, semi-specific interactions known as the +TIP network.[2] These interactions are typically described as being regulatory in nature; we proposed instead that the interactions of the +TIP network have a physical function, which is create a dynamic, cross-linked structure that stabilizes the growing microtubule tip.  This hypothesis is the topic of ongoing work.

• We used experiments to show that the MTBP EB1, which is recognized as one of the most functionally and evolutionarily significant MT binding proteins in eukaryotic cells, also binds to actin filaments.[3] This work provides new insight into the mechanisms by which different parts of the cytoskeleton are coordinated.

• We used a combination of simulations and experiments to help understand how the Alzheimer’s-associated MTBP Tau works, providing evidence that Tau stabilizes MTs primarily through binding laterally across the MT.[4] We also identified Tau as the first MTBP that prefers the GDP-rich MT lattice to the GTP-rich MT tip, potentially enabling cells to separately regulate the stability of the lattice (through Tau) and the tip (through tip-binding proteins).

• We laid the foundations for ongoing work by reexamining and clarifying fundamentally important questions such as amount of polymer expected from a given concentration of subunits.[5] 

 

BROADER IMPACTS

Broader impacts of this project include the following:

• Training: More than 12 undergraduates received research experience through this project, more than half of them female. Four cross-disciplinary PhD theses resulted. Two high school teachers and more than four school students also received training as part of this project.

• Teaching: Dr. Goodson continued to teach biology to ~250 freshman engineers, mathematicians and physicists and to serve as the Director of the Integrated Biomedical Sciences PhD program, a cross-disciplinary program she co-founded in 2012 to promote PhD training across disciplinary boundaries.

• National Service to the Scientific Community: Dr. Goodson served as a member of the ASCB Public Policy committee and is the incoming Chair of this committee. 

• Outreach: Throughout this project, Dr. Goodson and her group coached events (e.g., "Protein Modeling") for the Adams High School Science Olympiad team.

 

WORKS CITED

[1] Gupta KK, Li C, Duan AR, Alber MS, Goodson HV (2013). ‘A mechanism for the catastrophe-promoting activity of the microtubule destabilizer Op18/stathmin,’ PNAS, 110(51):20449-54

[2] Gupta KK, Alberico EO, Näthke IS, Goodson HV (2014). ‘Promoting microtubule assembly: A hypothesis for the functional significance of the +TIP network.’ Bioessays, 36(9):818-26.

 [3] Alberico EO, Zhu ZC, Wu YF, Gardner MK, Kovar DR, Goodson HV (2016). Interactions between the Microtubule Binding Protein EB1 and F-Actin. J Mol Biol. 2016 Mar 27;428(6):1304-14.

[4] Duan AR, Jonasson EM, Alberico EO, Li C, Scripture JP, Miller RA, Alber MS, Goodson HV (2017). Interactions between Tau and Different Conformations of Tubulin: Implications for Tau Function and Mechanism. J Mol Biol. 429(9):1424-1438.

[5] Jonasson EM, Mauro AJ, Li C, Labuz EC, Mahserejian SM, Scripture JP, Gregoretti IV, Alber M, Goodson HV (2019). Behaviors of individual microtubules and microtubule populations relative to critical concentrations. Mol Biol Cell (in press).
